name: Bryce Canyon National Park
description: Hoodoos (irregular columns of rock) exist on every continent, but here is the largest concentration found anywhere on Earth. Situated along a high plateau at the top of the Grand Staircase, the park's high elevations include numerous life communities, fantastic dark skies, and geological wonders that defy description.
shortDescription: Hoodoos (irregular columns of rock) exist on every continent, but here is the largest concentration found anywhere on Earth. Situated along a high plateau at the top of the Grand Staircase, the park's...

operatingHours.description: Bryce Canyon National Park is open 365 days a year, 24 hours a day.

fees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle
fees.description: Admits one private, non-commercial vehicle (15 passenger capacity or less) and all occupants.

fees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle
fees.description: Valid for 7 days. Admits up to 2 private, non-commercial motorcycles with up to 4 total passengers.

fees.title: Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: Admits one individual with no car to the park - typically used for bicyclists and walk-ins. Youth 15 and under are admitted free.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan
fees.description:
Commercial tour vehicle rates are based on vehicle capacity. Pass is valid for the day of purchase and the next six days for a vehicle carrying the same group of passengers.

A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees of commercial tours are based upon the total capacity of vehicles t

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van
fees.description:
Commercial tour vehicle rates are based on vehicle capacity. Pass is valid for the day of purchase and the next six days for a vehicle carrying the same group of passengers.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus
fees.description:
Commercial tour vehicle rates are based on vehicle capacity. Pass is valid for the day o

A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees of commercial tours are based upon the total capacity of vehicles that can carry seven or more passengers regardless of the actual number of passengers.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach
fees.description:
Commercial tour vehicle rates are based on vehicle capacity. Pass is valid for the day of purchase and the next six days for a vehicle carrying the same group of passengers.

A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees of commercial tours are based upon the total capacity of vehicles.

fees.title: Nonresident
fees.description: Each non-US resident aged 16 and older visiting Bryce Canyon National Park must pay a $100 nonresident fee (in addition to the standard entrance fee), unless admitted with an Annual or America the Beautiful Pass. This includes nonresidents entering as part of a commercial tour group, commercial use authorization (CUA) group, or concessioner tour group.

climate.weatherDescription: Due of its high elevation climate, weather at Bryce Canyon through autumn, winter, and spring can be highly variable. From October to May temperatures fall below freezing nearly every night. The park typically experiences its coldest and snowiest periods from December through February. Spring storms in March and April can still produce heavy snowfall that may impact travel in the region. Summer highs are typically in the 70s-80s F and afternoon thunderstorms are common in July and August.

images.title: Bryce Amphitheater from Inspiration Point
images.altText: A red rock landscape and plateau forest glows with the morning sun
images.caption: Viewpoints of the iconic Bryce Amphitheater are located along the first 3 miles of the park road and are a popular destination at sunrise.

images.title: Winter sunrise at Sunset Point
images.altText: Snow blankets a red rock landscape of tall rock spires beneath an early morning sky
images.caption: Here at 8,000' (2438 m) winter comes early and stays late. Snow transforms the landscape and requires seasonal closures in some areas and trails.

images.title: Milky Way over the Hoodoos
images.altText: The center of the Milky Way galaxy is seen rising above a horizon of forest and red rock spires
images.caption: Bryce Canyon's clean air and dark night skies are some of its most precious and vulnerable resources. Full moon nights also provide a unique experience of seeing the park after dark.

images.title: Queen's Garden Trail
images.altText: A lone white rock tower stands surrounded by red rock walls and forest along a trail
images.caption: More strenuous trails below the rim provide up-close views of the hoodoo rock spires, while easier walks along the rim give perspective from above.

images.title: Bristlecone Loop trail near Yovimpa Point
images.altText: Red and white rock cliffs lightly dusted with snow with a forest atop them and a long view beyond
images.caption: The park's highest elevations at its southern end and backcountry areas provide views of over 100 miles (161 km) atop high steep cliffs.
